content: The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2008 (P.L. 110-161) allocated $27.39 billion for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies, including funding for Department of the Interior, Forest Service, Indian Health Service, and Environmental Protection Agency. The annual bill includes funding for various agencies like the Smithsonian Institution, National Endowment for the Arts, and Department of Energy programs. Jurisdiction over DOE and EPA was consolidated in the 109th Congress. The House and Senate Appropriations subcommittees now cover Interior and Related Agencies after the abolition of the subcommittees on Veterans Affairs, Housing, and Urban Development. Appropriations laws since FY2006 have three main titles for funding Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies. The report is organized into sections for Interior agencies, EPA, other agencies, programs, and cross-cutting topics. The curr_chunk discusses key funding changes proposed for FY2008 in the Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies appropriations bill. It highlights the challenges of summarizing budget submissions and funding bills due to the extensive details involved. The report contains final FY2007 enacted levels for agencies and programs. The FY2007 figures used in this report differ from the FY2008 agency budget submissions due to agencies being funded under a short-term continuing resolution. Final FY2007 funding levels were determined by agencies under P.L. 110-5, which provided funds through September 30, 2007. The law required agencies to submit fund allocations below the account level to House and Senate Appropriations Committees within 30 days of enactment. Appropriations represent total funds available, including regular annual and supplemental appropriations, but exclude permanent mandatory budget authorities. Funding figures primarily come from the House Committee on Appropriations, with other sources including the Senate Committee on Appropriations, agency budget justifications, and the Congressional Record. Table 1 displays budget authority for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies from FY2004-FY2008. The President's FY2008 request of $25.69 billion would have been the lowest since FY2004, with a potential 6% decrease in funds. The House-approved funding was slightly higher than FY2004, while the Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended $27.19 billion. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended $27.19 billion for FY2008, a slight decrease from FY2004. The total funding of $27.39 billion included $500.0 million in emergency fire funding. The FY2008 funding for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies was part of the Consolidated Appropriations Act (P.L. 110-161) signed into law on December 26, 2007. The Consolidated Appropriations Act (P.L. 110-161), which included funding for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies, was signed into law on December 26, 2007. An explanatory statement in the Congressional Record detailed funding levels and earmarks, but did not reflect a 1.56% across-the-board cut provided in H.R. 2764. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2008 (P.L. 110-161) provided $26.89 billion for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies, reflecting a 1.56% cut. An additional $500.0 million in emergency appropriations for wildfires was included, bringing the total to $27.39 billion for FY2008. This amount was about the same as enacted for FY2007, but $240.2 million lower than the House's proposed amount for FY2008. The FY2008 budget for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies was $26.89 billion, with an additional $500 million for wildfires. The funds were allocated for various purposes including wildland fire management for the Forest Service and BLM. In FY2008, funds were allocated as follows: $40.0 million for suppression, $115.0 million for repayment of accounts borrowed in FY2007, $10.0 million for hazardous fuels reduction, and $6.0 million for rehabilitation of federal lands. The appropriations level varied for different agencies, with increases for some like the Forest Service and decreases for others like the Environmental Protection Agency. In FY2008, funding allocations included -$124.2 million for the EPA, -$43.6 million for the OSM, -$33.9 million for the OST, and -$27.19 billion for all agencies under the Interior. Continuing funding was necessary due to the lack of a regular FY2008 funding bill before the start of the fiscal year. In FY2008, funding allocations for various agencies were as follows: -$124.2 million for the EPA, -$43.6 million for the OSM, -$33.9 million for the OST, and $27.19 billion for all agencies under the Interior. The House passed H.R. 2643 with $27.63 billion for FY2008, an increase over the FY2007 level. The Senate committee level proposed a decrease from FY2007. Both House and Senate levels were higher than the President's request of $25.69 billion for FY2008. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered amendments, including one to remove language barring funds for new Outer Continental Shelf leases without price thresholds. The House considered 58 amendments to H.R. 2643, adopting 18 before passing the bill on June 27, 2007. Amendments addressed various programs and issues, including banning imports of polar bears and polar bear parts. Amendments to extend the Secure Rural Schools Act and expedite claims challenging land management plans were withdrawn. The bill aimed to compensate counties for tax-exempt national forests and public lands. The House Appropriations Committee reported H.R. 2643 with a total of $27.63 billion, and a supplemental report identified funded projects. Amendments to the bill included reducing appropriations or prohibiting funds for specific programs. During consideration of the annual Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Appropriations bill, funding and policy issues have been debated. The FY2008 funding levels were controversial, with key issues including Clean Water and Drinking Water State Revolving Funds for wastewater and drinking water infrastructure projects, and construction of BIA Schools and IHS Health Facilities, with debates on funding cuts proposed in the President's budget. The FY2008 funding levels for the Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Appropriations bill were controversial. Key issues included Clean Water and Drinking Water State Revolving Funds, construction of BIA Schools and IHS Health Facilities, Indian Trust Funds, Land Acquisition, and Outer Continental Shelf Leasing. The FY2008 funding levels for the Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Appropriations bill were controversial, with key issues including moratoria on preleasing and leasing activities in offshore areas, oil and gas leases in offshore California, Payments in Lieu of Taxes Program (PILT), Royalty Relief for oil and natural gas companies on federal lands, and Superfund funding for hazardous waste cleanup. Termination of BIA Education and Housing, IHS Urban Health Programs, and Wildland Fire Fighting funding issues were key concerns in the FY2008 Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Appropriations bill. The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) manages public land for various uses, including energy development, grazing, recreation, and preservation. They also oversee federal mineral resources and wildfire management on millions of acres of land. In FY2008, BLM received $1.89 billion in funding, including emergency appropriations for wildfires. For more information, refer to the "Bureau of Land Management" and "Department of Agriculture: Forest Service" sections in this report. In FY2008, the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) received $1.89 billion in funding, including $78.0 million in emergency appropriations for wildfire suppression. An additional $171.0 million in emergency wildfire funds was provided in a previous law, bringing the total BLM appropriation to $2.06 billion. This funding level was higher than FY2007 and was supported by the Administration, House, and Senate Appropriations Committee primarily due to the emergency appropriations for wildfires. The FY2008 law allocated $853.9 million for the management of lands and resources, which was lower than FY2007. The FY2008 Senate Appropriations Committee allocated $1.89 billion to the Bureau of Land Management, including $78.0 million for wildfire suppression. The law included $74.8 million for maintenance, $44.3 million for wildlife and fisheries, and $73.0 million for range management, with increases for deferred maintenance and the healthy lands initiative. The FY2008 law allocated $67.9 million for recreation and wilderness programs, with an increase for the healthy lands initiative to enhance vegetation resources on western public lands. The National Landscape Conservation System received about $5 million more than the President's request for its 26 million acres of protected conservation areas. The FY2008 law included lower funding for energy and minerals at $109.9 million, with a reduction achieved through offsetting fees. Revenues are expected from a new program requiring payment for drilling permits. The law also capped the appropriation for oil and gas management at $90.2 million due to concerns about fund usage. The FY2008 law included provisions to limit funding for oil and gas activities by BLM, specifically regarding oil shale leasing programs. The National Park Service (NPS) oversees 391 park units covering 85 million acres with a mission to protect and preserve natural and historic areas for public access. The NPS has over 20,000 employees and 20 types of area designations, including national parks, monuments, and recreational areas. Annual park visitation is at 273 million visits. The National Park Service (NPS) manages various park units across different landscapes and promotes resource conservation activities. The FY2008 appropriations law allocated $2.39 billion for the NPS, with plans to enhance visitor services and park programs for the NPS's 100th anniversary in 2016 through the National Parks Centennial Initiative. The Parks Centennial Initiative, introduced by President Bush in 2006, aims to provide up to $3 billion in new funds for national parks over 10 years through a public/private partnership. It includes adding $100 million annually in discretionary funds, challenging the public to donate $100 million annually, and matching public donations with federal funds. Concerns have been raised about potential commercialization and privatization influence on the parks. Park advocacy groups estimate a budget shortfall of over $600 million annually for national parks. The FY2008 law addressed a budget shortfall of over $600 million annually for national parks. It extended the authorization of the National Park System Advisory Board and did not include a transfer of $1.0 million for the Statue of Liberty. The Urban Parks and Recreation Recovery grant program has not been funded since FY2002. The House Appropriations Committee reminded the NPS of its responsibility to enforce regulations prohibiting the conversion of project sites for other uses. The FY2008 law did not provide new grant monies for UPARR. The NPS issued a Record of Decision on winter use management in Yellowstone, with lawsuits not requesting injunctions, allowing operations to continue. The law also repealed a provision prohibiting the NPS from removing nonnative deer. The FY2008 law prohibited the NPS from removing nonnative deer and elk from Santa Rosa Island in the Channel Islands National Park, impacting park operations funding. The law provided $1.97 billion for park operations, incorporating the Park Police account into the operations line item. The majority of operations funding is provided directly to park managers to support activities, programs, and services essential for day-to-day park operations. The FY2008 law allocated $1.74 billion for park management, with increases sought for maintenance, visitor services, and resource stewardship. The $24.6 million for state assistance was significantly less than the House and Senate proposals, as well as below the FY2007 enacted level. The Historic Preservation Fund (HPF) provides grants for restoring historic sites and objects, with NHPA reauthorization enacted in December 2006. The NHPA reauthorization (P.L. 109-235) extended funding authority for the HPF through 2015, with preservation grants funded on a federal-state matching basis. The FY2008 law allocated $70.4 million for the HPF, a 7% increase from FY2007. Grants to state historic preservation offices increased by 6% to $39.4 million. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) is a key science agency providing information on natural hazards, the environment, and energy. It is also a primary mapping agency and a source of water resource data. Funding for the USGS is allocated for various activities including geographic research and geologic investigations. The FY2008 law allocated $1.01 billion for the USGS, the first time its budget exceeded a billion dollars. This was $31.5 million (3%) over the Administration's request and $18.4 million (2%) over the FY2007 enacted level. Additionally, $6.3 million was provided for water resources research institutes and full funding for the mineral resource assessment program. An increase of $7.4 million was included for global climate change research, with $2.5 million directed to establish the National Global Warming and Wildlife Science Center. The FY2008 law provided $110.4 million for Enterprise Information within the USGS, slightly below the Administration's request. This program includes funding for information technology, security, services, and resources management. There are three main programs under Enterprise Information: enterprise information security and technology, enterprise information resources, and national geospatial program. The national geospatial program, managed by the Federal Geographic Data Committee (FGDC), aims to provide high-quality geospatial information to the public. The FY2008 law allocated $77.7 million for the program, with $24.2 million designated for the Landsat Data Continuity Mission (Landsat 8) to monitor the Earth's land surface and coastal areas. The Minerals Management Service (MMS) collects and distributes revenue from federal onshore and offshore leases, as well as Indian mineral leases. In FY2007, MMS collected $11.5 billion in revenue, with royalties from natural gas production accounting for 40-45% and oil royalties for 38.5% of receipts. The revenue fluctuates annually based on oil and gas prices. The Minerals Management Service (MMS) collects revenue from federal onshore and offshore leases, as well as Indian mineral leases. In FY2008, MMS had a funding level of $294.7 million, with appropriations of $115.9 million, offsetting collections of $135.7 million, and state cost sharing deductions of $43.0 million. This represented a $6.4 million (2%) increase from FY2007. The Senate recommended a budget of $302.1 million, while the House approved $295.7 million with less funding through appropriations. The FY2008 appropriations law included provisions for a $50.0 million deferral for ultra deepwater research and a $43.0 million deduction for state royalty administrative costs. Congress established net receipts sharing in 1991, requiring states to cover some administrative costs for federal leases.
